data.name: Tile Map Path Finding
data.description:
A game map is represented by a 2d array containing only integers, and can be a grid of any size. Each number in the 'map' represents an entity:

```
0 is an empty space
1 is the player
2 is a wall or object that can not be passed
```

For example:
```
map = [[0, 0, 1, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]]
```

Would be a map with the player at ```map[0][2]``` and 3 walls/objects at ```map[1][2], map[2][2] and map[3][2]```.

Your task is to implement a method ```find_path(map, end_point)``` which finds the most efficient path from the players position to the given end_point for the given map, moving only up, down, left or right.

There are a few noteable exceptions, which will require you to return an empty array ```[]``` i.e. there is no possible path. These are:
```
No player exists on the map (1)
The end_point location is already occupied with a wall/object (2)
It is impossible to create a path from the player to the end point
A nil end_point is given
The end_point is out of bounds of the map array
```

In all other cases a path should be returned as a 2d array, where the values are the co-ordinates for each step taken on the path, for example:
```ruby
map = [[0, 1, 2, 0, 0]]
find_path(map, [0, 4]) # Should return [] as it is impossible.
find_path(map, [0, 0]) # Should return [[0, 0]]
map = [[0, 1],
       [0, 0]]
find_path(map, [1, 0]) # Should return [[0, 0], [1, 0]] or [[1,1],[1,0]] depending on your code
map = [[0, 0, 0, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 2, 0, 0],
      [0, 0, 1, 0, 0]]
find_path(map, [1, 2]) # Should return [] as the end_point tile is occupied.
find_path(map, [0, 2]).length # Should be 6, as the path is 6 steps.
find_path(map, [0, 2]) # Should return either [[4,1],[3,1],[2,1],[1,1],[0,1],[0,2]] or [[4,3],[3,3],[2,3],[1,3],[0,3],[0,2]] depending on your code
```
